The flooding in the Midwest is also having a big impact on crops.
Prices for corn and soybeans were already high before the wet weather.
Now, they're hitting record levels on commodity exchanges.
Joining us now to tell us more is John Dimsdale from Marketplace.
John, where exactly are we in the crop cycle in the Midwest?
Well, we're very near the end of the planting window for that all-important crop, corn.
Ninety-five percent or more of that has already been planted, and much of it could be washed out.
But if the waters recede quickly, those fields could be replanted with a type of corn that grows more quickly.
Now, the success of that depends on good rains in August and no early frosts in fall.
And otherwise, corn farmers can plant - can switch to soybeans, which is another crop for animal feeds.
Soybeans can be planted until early July.
But these storms have come during a very sensitive time for farmers, because it's already been such a cold, wet spring.
You know, there's that comparison of the floods in 1993, which the government reports cost the nation 21 billion dollars in damages.
But Palle Pedersen, who's a soybean farmer and an agronomist at Iowa State University, says this year could be worse.
In 1993, we were able to get the crop planted at the right time, and then the flood came late, so it was in June and July.
This year, it's been cold and wet here since April, pretty much the whole spring.
But really, the problem is that the crop that was established and that is not under water right now is way behind in development.
And anticipation of these low crop yields has led to these record high prices that we've been talking about.
So, at those prices, will farmers still be able to make a profit?
Well, not according to Palle Pederson.
Here's what he says.
The farmers will not make more money this year because of these high prices, because the yields will not be there.
If you look at the production cost in the ag sector, because of the high energy costs, you know, things like nitrogen, and then, of course, land rents have gone up quite a lot.
So even though we have seen these prices over the last year, you know, that doesn't mean we're making more money.
And John, I've been thinking about this.
Prices at the grocery store have already been high.
Is it going to get even worse for consumers?
Probably, although, you know, there are a lot of variables.

So, the final prices depend on the weather in other parts of the world.
